elements.content: Four novel metal−organic coordination polymers, [Zn2(ppda)(phen)2(HCOO)2] (1), [Mn(ppda)(phen)(H2O)2]·DMF (2), [Zn(mpda)(phen)]·1.5H2O (3), and [Mn2(mpda)2(phen)2] (4), (H2ppda = p-phenylenediacrylic acid, H2mpda = m-phenylenediacrylic acid, and phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 consists of two-dimensional (2D) bilayers in which formate-bridged chains are cross-linked by ppda ligands, and the bilayers are sustained by infinite zipper-like π−π stacking of the phen ligands. Compounds 2 and 3 are both one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers, but exhibit different chain shapes due to the different geometry of ppda and mpda. Via O−H···O hydrogen bonding and pairwise phen···phen π−π stacking, the zigzag chains in 2 are assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) diamond network with 3-fold interpenetration, while the helical chains in 3 are packed into a 3D structure through quadruple π−π stacking arrays. Compound 4 is composed of double twist chains of binuclear units sustained by double carboxylate bridges and phen···phen π−π stacking. Magnetic investigations on 2 and 4 have been carried out. Compound 4 exhibits weak intradimer antiferromagnetic exchange mediated through the carboxylate bridges and the possible π−π stacking pathway, while much weaker antiferromagnetic exchange is operative through the interchain hydrogen bonding motif in 2.
elements.clean_text: Four novel metal-organic coordination polymers, [Zn2(ppda)(phen)2(HCOO)2] (1), [Mn(ppda)(phen)(H2O)2]⋅DMF (2), [Zn(mpda)(phen)]⋅1.5H2O (3), and [Mn2(mpda)2(phen)2] (4), (H2ppda = p-phenylenediacrylic acid, H2mpda = m-phenylenediacrylic acid, and phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 consists of two-dimensional (2D) bilayers in which formate-bridged chains are cross-linked by ppda ligands, and the bilayers are sustained by infinite zipper-like π-π stacking of the phen ligands. Compounds 2 and 3 are both one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers, but exhibit different chain shapes due to the different geometry of ppda and mpda. Via O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding and pairwise phen⋅⋅⋅phen π-π stacking, the zigzag chains in 2 are assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) diamond network with 3-fold interpenetration, while the helical chains in 3 are packed into a 3D structure through quadruple π-π stacking arrays. Compound 4 is composed of double twist chains of binuclear units sustained by double carboxylate bridges and phen⋅⋅⋅phen π-π stacking. Magnetic investigations on 2 and 4 have been carried out. Compound 4 exhibits weak intradimer antiferromagnetic exchange mediated through the carboxylate bridges and the possible π-π stacking pathway, while much weaker antiferromagnetic exchange is operative through the interchain hydrogen bonding motif in 2.

elements.content: Under hydrothermal conditions, the assembly of two different phenylenediacrylate ligands with Zn(II) and Mn(II) ions in the presence of phenanthroline as terminal ligands leads to distinct coordination polymers, including double layers, zigzag chains, helical chains, and double twist chains.
elements.clean_text: Under hydrothermal conditions, the assembly of two different phenylenediacrylate ligands with Zn(II) and Mn(II) ions in the presence of phenanthroline as terminal ligands leads to distinct coordination polymers, including double layers, zigzag chains, helical chains, and double twist chains.

elements.content: Metal−organic coordination polymers built from transition metal ions and organic bridging ligands have been rapidly developed in recent years, the interest arising not only from their fascinating structural beauty and diversity but also from their promising applications as functional materials. To date, a plethora of coordination frameworks have been successfully constructed, and crystal engineering has attained such a relatively mature level that some coordination networks with specific topologies can be “designed” by the judicious selection of metal ions and organic ligands. However, generally speaking, the designed synthesis of coordination networks and supramolecular architectures is still a difficult challenge in most cases, due to the flexibility and diversity of metal ions and organic ligands in coordination and noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding. The final structure is primarily determined by the geometric and electronic preferences of the metal ions and organic ligands, and can be strongly influenced by a number of other interplaying factors such as the medium, template, metal−ligand ratio, and other synthetic conditions. In this context, the search for new organic ligands with different coordination habits is still fundamental to crystal engineering of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic coordination polymers built from transition metal ions and organic bridging ligands have been rapidly developed in recent years, the interest arising not only from their fascinating structural beauty and diversity but also from their promising applications as functional materials. To date, a plethora of coordination frameworks have been successfully constructed, and crystal engineering has attained such a relatively mature level that some coordination networks with specific topologies can be "designed" by the judicious selection of metal ions and organic ligands. However, generally speaking, the designed synthesis of coordination networks and supramolecular architectures is still a difficult challenge in most cases, due to the flexibility and diversity of metal ions and organic ligands in coordination and noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding. The final structure is primarily determined by the geometric and electronic preferences of the metal ions and organic ligands, and can be strongly influenced by a number of other interplaying factors such as the medium, template, metal-ligand ratio, and other synthetic conditions. In this context, the search for new organic ligands with different coordination habits is still fundamental to crystal engineering of coordination polymers.

elements.content: The rigid and multidentate aromatic polycarboxylates, such as benzenedicarboxylates, benzenetricarboxylates, and biphenyldicarboxylates, are among the most extensively studied organic ligands in the construction of metal−organic coordination materials that have great relevance to gas storage, photoluminescence, magnetism, and other functions. We are interested in phenylenediacrylate ligands with different geometric features, as shown in Chart . The ligands inherit the advantages of the benzenedicarboxylate analogs, such as the rigidity arising from the extended conjugated structure, but have much longer spacers between the carboxylate groups. The coordination chemistry of these relatively simple ligands remains largely unexplored. To our knowledge, only a three-dimensional (3D) metal−organic framework of p-phenylenediacrylate (ppda) has been reported recently, and no coordination compounds with m-phenylenediacrylate (mpda) have been reported up to now. In this article, we report the syntheses and structures of four metal−organic coordination polymers of ppda and mpda with divalent transitional metal ions (Mn, Zn), formulated as [Zn2(ppda)(phen)2(HCOO)2] (1), [Mn(ppda)(phen)(H2O)2]·(DMF) (2), [Zn(mpda)(phen)]·1.5H2O (3), and [Mn2(mpda)2(phen)2] (4), where phen = 1,10-phenanthroline. The magnetic properties of compounds 2 and 4 are also included.

elements.content: All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available. H2ppda and H2mpda were synthesized by literature methods. Elemental analyses were determined on a Vario ELIII Elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 500−4000 cm−1 using KBr pellets on a Nicolet NEXUS 670 spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument under flowing air at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα at a scan speed of 1° min−1. Temperature-dependent magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-5 magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available. H2ppda and H2mpda were synthesized by literature methods. Elemental analyses were determined on a Vario ELIII Elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 500-4000 cm-1 using KBr pellets on a Nicolet NEXUS 670 spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument under flowing air at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα at a scan speed of 1° min-1. Temperature-dependent magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-5 magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 0.030 g), phen (0.1 mmol, 0.02 g), H2ppda (0.1 mmol, 0.022 g) in DMF (4 mL), and distilled water (2 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, and then heated in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave at 110 °C for 4 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature slowly, colorless parallelepiped block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed with water and ethanol, Yield, 0.017 g (52% based on Zn). Element analysis. Calc. (%) for C38H26N4O8Zn2: C 57.2, H 3.29, N 7.03. Found: C 56.8, H 3.59, N 6.96. IR (KBr, ν/cm−1: 1680w, 1630s, 1570s, 1550sh, 1511m, 1420s, 1390s, 1090m, 980m, 862m, 725m, 509w.

elements.content: Diffraction data for 1, 2, 3, and 4 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Apex II CCD area detector equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2, with all non-hydrogen atoms refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using the riding model. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 2 and 3 were located from the difference maps. The water molecules in 3 are heavily disordered. The structure of 1 was solved in the noncentric Pca21 space group with twinning. The twin law 100, 010, 001̅ was applied and the Flack parameter was refined to be 0.01(24). A summary of the crystallographic data, data collection, and refinement parameters for complexes 1−4 are provided in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Measurements

Diffraction data for 1, 2, 3, and 4 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Apex II CCD area detector equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2, with all non-hydrogen atoms refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using the riding model. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 2 and 3 were located from the difference maps. The water molecules in 3 are heavily disordered. The structure of 1 was solved in the noncentric Pca21 space group with twinning. The twin law 100, 010, 001̅ was applied and the Flack parameter was refined to be 0.01(24). A summary of the crystallographic data, data collection, and refinement parameters for complexes 1-4 are provided in Table .

Complex 1 was synthesized from Zn(NO3)2, H2ppda, and phen in DMF/H2O at 110 °C, involving the in situ formation of formate from the decomposition of DMF. It is well-known that DMF can undergo the hydrolytic reaction to release formate and dimethylamine slowly at high temperature and/or under acidic conditions, and the reaction has been used to synthesize some transition metal formates under hydrothermal conditions. However, complex 1 could not be obtained in the absence of DMF, using formic acid or sodium formate as the formate source. Compound 2 was synthesized under the same reaction conditions, but the formate ion was not found in the final product. When the reactions were carried out with H2mpda in the mixed DMF/H2O solvent, no characterizable products were obtained. Although H2ppda and H2mpda are nearly insoluble in water, they can be easily dissolved in water solutions in the presence of some weakly basic reagents such as HCOONa and NaHCO3. Therefore, the reactions of the ligands and appropriate metal salts in water solutions containing HCOONa were carried out. It turned out that the reaction using H2mpda gave compounds 3 and 4, but the reactions using H2ppda yielded only uncharacterized precipitates. It is noted that the formate ion is also absent in compounds 3 and 4. Apparently, HCOONa acts only as a base to deprotonate the carboxylic group. The same compounds could be obtained by replacing HCOONa with NaHCO3, as have been proven by infrared spectra and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Our efforts to obtain the compounds via nonhydrothermal procedures were in vain.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and General Characterization

Complex 1 was synthesized from Zn(NO3)2, H2ppda, and phen in DMF/H2O at 110 °C, involving the in situ formation of formate from the decomposition of DMF. It is well-known that DMF can undergo the hydrolytic reaction to release formate and dimethylamine slowly at high temperature and/or under acidic conditions, and the reaction has been used to synthesize some transition metal formates under hydrothermal conditions. However, complex 1 could not be obtained in the absence of DMF, using formic acid or sodium formate as the formate source. Compound 2 was synthesized under the same reaction conditions, but the formate ion was not found in the final product. When the reactions were carried out with H2mpda in the mixed DMF/H2O solvent, no characterizable products were obtained. Although H2ppda and H2mpda are nearly insoluble in water, they can be easily dissolved in water solutions in the presence of some weakly basic reagents such as HCOONa and NaHCO3. Therefore, the reactions of the ligands and appropriate metal salts in water solutions containing HCOONa were carried out. It turned out that the reaction using H2mpda gave compounds 3 and 4, but the reactions using H2ppda yielded only uncharacterized precipitates. It is noted that the formate ion is also absent in compounds 3 and 4. Apparently, HCOONa acts only as a base to deprotonate the carboxylic group. The same compounds could be obtained by replacing HCOONa with NaHCO3, as have been proven by infrared spectra and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). Our efforts to obtain the compounds via nonhydrothermal procedures were in vain.

elements.content: The IR spectra of these compounds show characteristic absorption bands attributable to the carboxylate stretching vibrations. They all exhibit a strong absorption in the range of 1630−1645 cm−1, which may be assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode, and the strong bands at about 1390 cm−1 are attributable to the symmetric stretching mode. The spectrum of 1 shows strong bands at about 1570 and 1420 cm−1, assignable to the formate group.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on compounds 1−4 (see ). Complex 1 exhibits a weight loss of 5.5% from 138 to 248 °C, indicating the decomposition and release of one formate ligand per formula (calcd. 5.64%), and up to 300 °C, both formate ligands are released and the framework starts to decompose. For compound 2, the first weight loss of 19% occurs at about 118 °C, which is attributed to the evacuation of the free solvent DMF and coordinated H2O molecules (calcd. 19.4%), and the weight loss above 300 °C should correspond to the decomposition of the framework. TGA of 3 suggested that the release of the guest water molecules begins at about 75 °C (weight loss: 5.4%, calcd. 5.5%). The decomposition of the framework occurs above 280 °C. The TGA curve of compound 4 shows no appreciable weight loss up to 260 °C, after which a slow decomposition of the framework occurs.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography revealed that the structure consists of two-dimensional (2D) coordination networks with formate and ppda as bridging ligands. Selected bond parameters are listed in Table , and the structure is depicted in Figure . The asymmetric unit contains two zinc(II) ions, a ppda ligand, two 1,10-phen molecules, and two formate ions (Figure a). Each metal ion is five-coordinated by a chelating phen, a carboxylate oxygen atom from ppda, and two oxygen atoms from different formate ions, with a highly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The equatorial plane for each Zn(II) is decorated by a phen nitrogen (N4 or N1), a formate oxygen (O1 or O3), and a ppda carboxylate oxygen (O5 or O7), and the remaining phen nitrogen (N3 or N2) and formate oxygen (O2 or O4) reside at the axial positions. The Zn−O bond distances are in the range of 1.997(12)−2.109(11) Å, and the Zn−N bond distances are somewhat longer, ranging from 2.072(11) to 2.225(10) Å. In the equatorial planes, the N4−Zn1−O5 and N1−Zn2−O7 angles (ca. 150°) deviate much from the ideal angle of 120°, with the other equatorial angles around metal centers being in the range of 99−109°. The increased space between N4 and O5 (or between N1 and O7) is related to the weak coordination of the second oxygen atom (O6 for Zn1 or O8 for Zn2) from the ppda carboxylate group. The weak interactions are characterized by the rather long distances of Zn1−O6 = 2.703(11) Å and Zn2−O8 = 2.704(11) Å. Taking into account the weak coordination, the coordination geometry around each Zn is a highly distorted octahedron.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description

Compound 1 

X-ray crystallography revealed that the structure consists of two-dimensional (2D) coordination networks with formate and ppda as bridging ligands. Selected bond parameters are listed in Table , and the structure is depicted in Figure . The asymmetric unit contains two zinc(II) ions, a ppda ligand, two 1,10-phen molecules, and two formate ions (Figure a). Each metal ion is five-coordinated by a chelating phen, a carboxylate oxygen atom from ppda, and two oxygen atoms from different formate ions, with a highly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The equatorial plane for each Zn(II) is decorated by a phen nitrogen (N4 or N1), a formate oxygen (O1 or O3), and a ppda carboxylate oxygen (O5 or O7), and the remaining phen nitrogen (N3 or N2) and formate oxygen (O2 or O4) reside at the axial positions. The Zn-O bond distances are in the range of 1.997(12)-2.109(11) Å, and the Zn-N bond distances are somewhat longer, ranging from 2.072(11) to 2.225(10) Å. In the equatorial planes, the N4-Zn1-O5 and N1-Zn2-O7 angles (ca. 150°) deviate much from the ideal angle of 120°, with the other equatorial angles around metal centers being in the range of 99-109°. The increased space between N4 and O5 (or between N1 and O7) is related to the weak coordination of the second oxygen atom (O6 for Zn1 or O8 for Zn2) from the ppda carboxylate group. The weak interactions are characterized by the rather long distances of Zn1-O6 = 2.703(11) Å and Zn2-O8 = 2.704(11) Å. Taking into account the weak coordination, the coordination geometry around each Zn is a highly distorted octahedron.

elements.content: There are two independent sets of formate ions in the structure, both adopting the anti-anti bridging mode. The O1−C1−O2 and O3−C2−O4 formate ions link the Zn1 and Zn2 metal ions, respectively, to give two independent sets of infinite one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chains along the a axis, with Zn···Zn = 5.635 and 5.659 Å. The chelating phen ligands attached to each zigzag chain are arranged on opposite sides of the chain, and the ligands from neighboring chains are interdigitated in a parallel and zipper-like fashion (Figure b). There are evident face-to-face π−π stacking interactions between the interdigitated ligands, with the overlapping mainly occurring between the quinoline moieties. The π−π stacking alignment of the zigzag chains leads to [Zn(HCOO)(phen)] n layers parallel to the ab plane. It should be noted that two independent sets of layers are formed from Zn1 and Zn2, respectively. The interplane and center-to-center distances for the π−π stacking interactions are respectively 3.558(9) and 3.699(2) Å in the Zn1 layer, and 3.507(13) and 3.686(2) Å in the Zn2 layer.

The chelating phen ligands attached to each zigzag chain are arranged on opposite sides of the chain, and the ligands from neighboring chains are interdigitated in a parallel and zipper-like fashion (Figure b). There are evident face-to-face π-π stacking interactions between the interdigitated ligands, with the overlapping mainly occurring between the quinoline moieties. The π-π stacking alignment of the zigzag chains leads to [Zn(HCOO)(phen)] n  layers parallel to the ab plane. It should be noted that two independent sets of layers are formed from Zn1 and Zn2, respectively. The interplane and center-to-center distances for the π-π stacking interactions are respectively 3.558(9) and 3.699(2) Å in the Zn1 layer, and 3.507(13) and 3.686(2) Å in the Zn2 layer.

elements.content: The ppda ligand serves as a long bridge between Zn1 and Zn2 atoms, with each carboxylate group in the monodentate mode (or a highly asymmetric chelating mode, taking into account the weak coordination of O6 and O8). The Zn1···Zn2 distance separated by ppda is 15.354 Å. As shown in Figure c, each Zn1 (or Zn2) chain from one [Zn(HCOO)(phen)] n layer is cross-linked to two Zn2 (or Zn1) chains from another layer, by two equivalent sets of ppda linkers that are slanted with respect to each other. Therefore, a Zn1 layer and a Zn2 layer, both formed through formate bridges and π−π interactions, are pillared by the long ppda ligands to generate a very thick bilayer extending along the ab plane. Topologically, each Zn(phen) moiety may be taken as a five-connecting node (two formate connections, a ppda one, and two π−π ones), and then the bilayer network can be reduced to a 2D net with the Schläfli notation 44·66, as illustrated in Figure d. Neglecting the π−π stacking connections (the dotted lines in Figure d), the coordination network becomes a highly undulated variant of the (6,3) net, with each Zn ion as a three-connecting node (two short formate bridges and a much longer ppda bridge).

elements.content: The bilayers are stacked in a complementary way, with the π−π stacked phen moieties from one bilayer pointing to the Zn(HCOO) chain moieties of another bilayer. Such arrangement allows for the formation of weak C−H···O hydrogen bonds (Figure c): the C23−H and C28−H groups of different phen molecules from a bilayer interact respectively with the O4 and O2 atoms of different formate ions from neighboring bilayers. The relevant parameters are C23···O4 = 3.262(19) Å, H23A···O4 =2.38 Å, C23−H23A···O4 = 157.47°, and C28···O2 = 3.313(22) Å, H28A···O2 = 2.44 Å, C28−H28A···O2 = 155.51°.

elements.content: This compound consists of zigzag chains. The Mn(II) ion exhibits a distorted cis-octahedral coordination geometry completed by a chelate phen molecule, two monodentate carboxylate groups, and two coordination water molecules (Figure a). The Mn−O bond distances range from 2.112(2) to 2.226(2) Å, and the Mn−N bond distances are somewhat longer (Table ). The geometrical distortion mainly arises from the small angle of chelating phen ligand (N(2)−Mn1−N(1) = 72.56°). The Mn(II) ions are bridged alternately by two independent sets of ppda ligands to generate an infinite chain along the (212) direction. Each ppda resides at an inversion center and has two monodentate carboxylate groups. The Mn···Mn distances separated by the ligands are 15.541 and 16.426 Å. The zigzag shape of the chain is dictated by the combination of the cis-octahedral geometry of the metal ion and the rigid quasi-linear geometry of the ligand. As shown in Figure a, the chain is reinforced by intrachain hydrogen bonds involving the coordinated water molecules (O5, O6) and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygens (O2, O4). The relevant geometric parameters, O−H···O angles and O···O distances are respectively 143.45° and 2.658(8) Å for O5···O4, and 167.08° and 2.600(4) Å for O6···O2. These lead to two cyclic hydrogen-bonded motifs with graph set R1 1(6) around each metal ion [according to Etter, the graph set notation describes a six-membered hydrogen-bonded ring including a donor atom (hydrogen) and an acceptor (oxygen in the present case)].

All the chains in 2 are packed in parallel and two types of interchain interactions are operative. First, the O6 coordinated water molecule one chain contributes a hydrogen atom to the uncoordinated carboxylate O4 atom from another chain, with O6−H···O4A = 175.10° and O6···O4A = 2.676(7) Å (A = 2 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z). The strong hydrogen bonding interactions link adjacent chains in a corner-to-corner fashion to produce a hydrogen-bonded 2D network along the (122̅) plane (Figure b), in which neighboring corners (the metal coordination spheres) from different chains are connected in pairs through pairs of complementary hydrogen bonds. Taking the double hydrogen-bonding motif as the connection besides the ppda ligand, the 2D layer can be regarded as a (6,3) network. The Mn···Mn distance separated by the hydrogen bonding motifs is 6.720(2) Å, much shorter than that by the ppda ligand. Second, as shown in Figure c, the terminal phen ligands from different chains are arranged in a face-to-face pairwise fashion to facilitate relatively strong π−π stacking interactions. The interplane and centroid−centroid distances are 3.47 and 3.88 Å, respectively. The π−π interactions also arrange the zigzag chains in a corner-to-corner fashion to produce an undulated 2D layer along (101̅), which may also be regarded as a (6,3) net, taking the π−π stacked phen···phen motifs as additional connections between Mn nodes. The Mn···Mn distance separated by the phen···phen motif is 9.85 Å. As a whole, the zigzag chains in 2 are assembled into a 3D supramolecular architecture via the hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking interactions. Topologically, the architecture can be regarded as a 3D diamond net, generated by the two sets of (6,3) net layers sharing the zigzag coordination chains (Figure d). The structure exhibits 3-fold interpenetration, as illustrated in Figure e. The large void space in a single net is mainly occupied through interpenetration, leaving small and irregular channels along the a direction, in which DMF solvent molecules are enclosed (). The DMF molecule is associated to the zigzag chain through the strong hydrogen bond between the coordinated O5 water molecule from the chain and the carbonyl oxygen (O7) from DMF, with O···O = 2.72 Å, O−H···O = 161.96°.

elements.content: The structure consists of 1D helical coordination chains. The Zn(II) ion has an octahedral environment formed by three chelating bidentate ligands: a phen molecule (N1 and N2) and two carboxylic groups (O1, O2, O3, and O4) from two mpda ligands. The metal octahedron is highly distorted, owing to the small O−Zn−O bite angles (<60°) and asymmetric Zn−O distances (the differences in Zn−O lengths are larger than 0.3 Å) of the chelating carboxylate groups (Table ). The mpda ligands serve as bis(chelating) bridges to link the metal ions into infinite helical chains running along the c-axis, with the Zn···Zn distance separated by mpda being 12.92 Å. The thread pitch (18.76 Å) is equal to the c dimension of the unit cell, corresponding to the next-nearest Zn···Zn distance along the chain. The benzene moieties of the V-shaped mpda ligand point away from the helical axis to generate a hollow cylinder, which is filled with disordered lattice water molecules (O6 and O7).

The centrosymmetric lattice of 3 is a mixture of parallel right- and left-handed helical chains, which alternate along the a and b directions (Figure c). The packing of the helical chains is sustained by complicated π−π stacking interactions involving all the phen molecules and the phenylene rings from the mpda ligands (Figure d). Each phenylene ring from one chain interacts with a phen ring from another chain of the same handedness, with the interplane and center-to-center distances being 3.48 and 3.70 Å, respectively, and each phen ring is involved in an additional π−π interaction with another phen ring from a chain of the opposite handedness, with the interplane and center-to-center distances being 3.55 and 3.61 Å, respectively. Consequently, as shown in Figure e, each helical chain is linked to six others (four with the same handedness and two with the opposite handedness). Figure d shows the interactions between four neighboring chains. It is evident that two phen groups are sandwiched between two phenylene rings through π−π interactions.

elements.content: The structure consists of twisted double chains based on binuclear units. Each Mn is six-coordinated and adopts a distorted octahedral environment formed by a chelating phen ligand, a chelating carboxylate group from an mpda, and two carboxylate oxygens from another two mpda ligands (Figure a). The equatorial plane for Mn1 is decorated by a phen nitrogen (N1), a chelating carboxylate (O3 and O4), and a monodentate carboxylate (O1), and the remaining monodentate carboxylate oxygen (O2) and phen nitrogen (N2) reside at the axial positions. The Mn−O bond distances are in the range of 2.084−2.452 Å, and the Mn−N bond distances range from 2.272 to 2.315 Å (Table ). The Mn(II) octahedron is highly distorted, evidenced by the small O−Mn−O bite angle (56.06°) and highly asymmetric Mn−O distances (2.185 versus 2.452 Å) of the chelating carboxylate.

Different from that in 3, the mpda ligand serves as a μ3 bridge with a chelating carboxylate and a bridging one. Mn1 and Mn1A, related by a 2-fold axis, are linked into a binuclear unit by two crystallographically equivalent carboxylate bridges with Mn···Mn = 4.051(6) Å. The bridge adopts an asymmetric syn-syn coordination mode with similar Mn−O distances but distinct C−O−Mn angles (120.02° vs 156.1°). It is interesting to note that the binuclear unit may be reinforced by aromatic π−π stacking interactions: The phen ligands attached to the two metal ions are parallel and overlap in a face-to-face fashion, with the interplane and center-to-center distances being 3.558(9) and 3.943(2) Å, respectively. Each binuclear unit is connected to two others through four mpda ligands, generating a 1D twisted double chain along the [101] direction, as shown in Figure a. The nearest interdimer Mn···Mn distance spanned by the mpda ligand is 14.302 Å.

elements.content: We have described four structures with different ligands or metal ions. The structures are quite different, depending upon the nature of the ligand and the metal ion. It is impossible to predict or rationalize the formation of each structure, because the outcomes of the assembly are not only dependent upon the subtle interplay between the metal ion and the ligand but also strongly influenced by other factors such as the solvent system. By choosing the two phenylenediacrylate ligands with different geometries (quasi-linear and V-shaped for the para and meta ligands, respectively), we hoped to explore the role of the ligand geometry toward the rational design. The unexpected (though not surprising) involvement of the formate ligand in 1 is disadvantageous to the purpose. Nevertheless, some preliminary information about how the ligand geometry influences the framework topology can be drawn from the structures of 2 and 3, which consist of singly bridged zigzag and helical chains, respectively. In 3, the helical shape of the chain arises from the combination of the asymmetry (chirality) of the metal coordination environment and the V-shaped geometry of the bis(chelating) meta ligand. The octahedral metal center surrounded by three chelating ligands (a phen molecule and two carboxylate groups) is intrinsically chiral, and the mpda ligands serve as unsymmetric linkers between metal centers of the same chiral configuration to generate a homochiral chain. The V-shaped geometry of the linkers shapes the homochiral chain into a helix (note that a homochiral chain is not necessarily helical. A linear linker can lead to a homochiral zigzag chain). As can be seen from Figure b, the helicity of the chain is determined by the configuration of the metal center: the Δ-configured metal center leads to a right-handed helix, and the Λ-configured metal center leads to a left-handed helix. In 2, the metal center, which is furnished by a chelating ring and two hydrogen-bonding rings (Figure a), is also chiral. However, the ppda linker is linear and centrosymmetric, and hence the outcome is the zigzag chain with alternate Λ- and Λ-configured metal centers. It should be mentioned that the bidentate phen ligand plays a critical role in directing the formation of the chains (by blocking two adjacent coordination sites) and in assembling the chains into 3D architectures (by forming interchain π−π stacking arrays). Compared to that of 3, the structure of 4 is peculiar in that it consists of double chains based on carboxylate bridged dimeric units with intradimer π−π interactions. It is unclear why the replacement of Zn(II) with Mn(II) results in such a dramatic change in structure. The structural impact of the V-shaped geometry of the mpda ligand is still evident in 4. First, the fashion in which the binuclear units in 4 are doubly interlinked is only possible for a V-shaped dicarboxylate ligand. Second, the double chain may be regarded as two distorted helical chains, again reflecting the high adaptability of the mpda ligand to helical structures. As shown in Figure b, the two helical chains share the binuclear units, have a common axis but the opposite handedness, and are related by inversion centers residing at the midpoint between neighboring binuclear units.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility in the range of 2−300 K for 4 was measured at 1000 Oe and shown as χM−T and χM T−T plot in Figure (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Mn(II) ion). The χM value increases as the temperature decreases, reaching a maximum of 0.288 emu mol−1 at about 4 K, and then decreases on further cooling. The χM T value at room temperature is 4.30 emu K mol−1, corresponding to the spin-only value of 4.38 emu K mol−1 expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. The χM T value decreases monotonically upon cooling and tends to vanish when the temperature approaches zero, indicating the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interaction between the metal ions. The thermal dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility obeys the Curie−Weiss law with C = 4.33 emu K mol−1 and θ = −4.56 K. The negative Weiss constant confirms the antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility in the range of 2-300 K for 4 was measured at 1000 Oe and shown as χM-T and χM T-T plot in Figure  (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Mn(II) ion). The χM value increases as the temperature decreases, reaching a maximum of 0.288 emu mol-1 at about 4 K, and then decreases on further cooling. The χM T value at room temperature is 4.30 emu K mol-1, corresponding to the spin-only value of 4.38 emu K mol-1 expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. The χM T value decreases monotonically upon cooling and tends to vanish when the temperature approaches zero, indicating the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interaction between the metal ions. The thermal dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility obeys the Curie-Weiss law with C = 4.33 emu K mol-1 and θ = -4.56 K. The negative Weiss constant confirms the antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) ions.

elements.content: According to X-ray crystallographic analyses, the structure of 4 consists of double carboxylate-bridged dimers that are interlinked into 1D chains by the mpda ligands. Considering the large separation between the dimers spanned by the long mpda ligand, the interdimer magnetic interactions should be negligible, if any. Therefore, the magnetic analysis was carried out using the spin Hamiltonian H = −J S 1 ·S 2 for Mn(II) dimers, where J stands for the intradimer interaction parameters. The expression of molar susceptibility is χ M = ( 2 N g 2 β 2 / k T ) ( A / B ) with A = 55 + 30 e 5 x + 14 e 9 x + 5 e 12 x + e 14 x B = 11 + 9 e 5 x + 7 e 9 x + 5 e 12 x + 3 e 14 x + e 15 x where x = −J/kT. The fit of the experimental data to this expression with g fixed at 2.00 is quite satisfactory, leading to J = −1.12 cm−1, with R = Σ(χobsd − χcalcd)2/Σχobsd 2 = 8.0 × 10−5. The J value indicates a weak antiferromagnetic interaction within the dimer. This is consistent with other Mn(II) systems with syn-syn carboxylate bridges. It should be noted that the magnetic exchange in the present compound may also have a contribution from the π−π interaction pathway, which involves directly ligating the relevant metal ions. Here the two phen ligands involved in the π−π interaction have the same coordination orientation, and the two chelated metal ions are on the same side of the phen···phen pair with a very short Mn···Mn distance (∼ 4.05 Å). Consequently, the two C−N−M−N−C chelating rings are also involved in the π−π interaction, providing a feasible pathway for magnetic exchange. Such a π−π interaction mode is different from that observed in 2. In 2, the two phen ligands have opposite orientations, the two metal ions are on different sides of the phen···phen pair with a much longer Mn···Mn distance (∼ 9.85 Å), and the chelating rings are not involved in the π−π interaction. Therefore, the π−π interaction in 2 does not provide a good pathway for magnetic exchange (see below).

elements.content: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of 2 was also measured (). The χM T value at room temperature is 4.37 emu K mol−1, corresponding to the value expected for magnetically isolated Mn(II). The χM T value shows a negligibly small decrease from 300 to 80 K, and then decreases more and more rapidly upon further cooling. The susceptibility data obey the Curie−Weiss law with C = 4.38 emu K mol−1 and θ = −0.31 K. The above features may be due to antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) ions and/or the zero-field splitting (ZFS) effect.

elements.content: Magnetic analysis was first carried out by considering only the ZFS effect of single Mn(II) ions. Using the susceptibility expression derived from the Hamiltonian H ZFS = D[S z 2 − S(S + 1)/3] (D is the zero-field splitting parameter for Mn(II) in an axial field), the fit of the magnetic data of 2 led to ∥D∥ ∼ 2 cm−1. This value is unrealistically large because ZFS for a high-spin octahedral Mn(II) ion is usually very small  of the order D ∼ 10−2 cm−1. Therefore, it is most likely that the temperature-dependent magnetic behavior of 2 is mainly owing to magnetic interactions between metal ions. According to the structural data, there are three types of exchange pathways between metal ions in 2: the ppda bridging ligands, the phen···phen π−π interaction motif and the O−H···O hydrogen bonding motif (Figure a−c). Because the Mn···Mn distances separated by the ppda ligands (15.5 and 16.4 Å) and the π−π interaction motif (9.85 Å) are much larger that separated by the hydrogen bonding motif (6.72 Å), we suggest that the hydrogen bonding motif is the dominating pathway for magnetic coupling. Thus, the system of 1 can magnetically be treated as a hydrogen-bonded dimeric Mn2 system. The fit of experimental magnetic data to eq led to g = 2.00 and J = −0.080 cm−1 with R = 5.8 × 10−5. The small ∣J∣ value suggests very weak antiferromagnetic coupling through the hydrogen bonding motif. It should be noted that the value may be overestimated because the fit did not include the ZFS effect, which may have some contribution to the χM T decrease at very low temperature.

elements.content: We have described four Zn(II) and Mn(II) coordination polymers of two different phenylenediacrylate ligands (ppda and mpda). The structures of these compounds are distinct from one another. In compound 1, both formate and ppda serve as bridges to link Zn ions into 2D bilayers, which are sustained by infinite zipper-like π−π stacking of the phen ligands and extended into a 3D architecture through weak C−H···O hydrogen bonds. Compounds 2 and 3 are both 1D coordination polymers, but exhibit different chain shapes (zigzag for 2 and helical for 3) due to the different geometry of ppda and mpda. Via O−H···O hydrogen bonding and pairwise phen···phen π−π stacking, the zigzag chains in 2 are assembled into a 3D diamond network with 3-fold interpenetration, while the helical chains in 3 are packed into a 3D structure through π−π stacking arrays involving two mpda and two phen ligands. In 4, dimeric units sustained by double carboxylate bridges and phen···phen π−π interactions are linked into double twist chains. Magnetic investigations on 2 and 4 have been carried out. Compound 4 exhibits weak intradimer antiferromagnetic exchange mediated through the carboxylate bridges and the possible π−π stacking pathway, while much weaker antiferromagnetic exchange is operative through the interchain hydrogen bonding motif in 2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have described four Zn(II) and Mn(II) coordination polymers of two different phenylenediacrylate ligands (ppda and mpda). The structures of these compounds are distinct from one another. In compound 1, both formate and ppda serve as bridges to link Zn ions into 2D bilayers, which are sustained by infinite zipper-like π-π stacking of the phen ligands and extended into a 3D architecture through weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. Compounds 2 and 3 are both 1D coordination polymers, but exhibit different chain shapes (zigzag for 2 and helical for 3) due to the different geometry of ppda and mpda. Via O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding and pairwise phen⋅⋅⋅phen π-π stacking, the zigzag chains in 2 are assembled into a 3D diamond network with 3-fold interpenetration, while the helical chains in 3 are packed into a 3D structure through π-π stacking arrays involving two mpda and two phen ligands. In 4, dimeric units sustained by double carboxylate bridges and phen⋅⋅⋅phen π-π interactions are linked into double twist chains. Magnetic investigations on 2 and 4 have been carried out. Compound 4 exhibits weak intradimer antiferromagnetic exchange mediated through the carboxylate bridges and the possible π-π stacking pathway, while much weaker antiferromagnetic exchange is operative through the interchain hydrogen bonding motif in 2.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on compounds 1−4 (see ). Complex 1 exhibits a weight loss of 5.5% from 138 to 248 °C, indicating the decomposition and release of one formate ligand per formula (calcd. 5.64%), and up to 300 °C, both formate ligands are released and the framework starts to decompose. For compound 2, the first weight loss of 19% occurs at about 118 °C, which is attributed to the evacuation of the free solvent DMF and coordinated H2O molecules (calcd. 19.4%), and the weight loss above 300 °C should correspond to the decomposition of the framework. TGA of 3 suggested that the release of the guest water molecules begins at about 75 °C (weight loss: 5.4%, calcd. 5.5%). The decomposition of the framework occurs above 280 °C. The TGA curve of compound 4 shows no appreciable weight loss up to 260 °C, after which a slow decomposition of the framework occurs.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility in the range of 2−300 K for 4 was measured at 1000 Oe and shown as χM−T and χM T−T plot in Figure (χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility per Mn(II) ion). The χM value increases as the temperature decreases, reaching a maximum of 0.288 emu mol−1 at about 4 K, and then decreases on further cooling. The χM T value at room temperature is 4.30 emu K mol−1, corresponding to the spin-only value of 4.38 emu K mol−1 expected for a magnetically isolated high-spin Mn(II) (S = 5/2) ion with g = 2.00. The χM T value decreases monotonically upon cooling and tends to vanish when the temperature approaches zero, indicating the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interaction between the metal ions. The thermal dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility obeys the Curie−Weiss law with C = 4.33 emu K mol−1 and θ = −4.56 K. The negative Weiss constant confirms the antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) ions.

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of 2 was also measured (). The χM T value at room temperature is 4.37 emu K mol−1, corresponding to the value expected for magnetically isolated Mn(II). The χM T value shows a negligibly small decrease from 300 to 80 K, and then decreases more and more rapidly upon further cooling. The susceptibility data obey the Curie−Weiss law with C = 4.38 emu K mol−1 and θ = −0.31 K. The above features may be due to antiferromagnetic interactions between Mn(II) ions and/or the zero-field splitting (ZFS) effect.
